97698.name: World trade (% of GDP) (PWT 9.0)
97698.description: Sum of world exports and imports as a share of world GDP (%).
97698.datasetName: Globalization over 5 centuries - PWT 9.0, Klasing & Milionis (2014), and Estevadeordal, Frantz, and Taylor (2003)

source.name: Penn World Tables 9.0
source.dataPublishedBy: Feenstra, Robert C., Robert Inklaar and Marcel P. Timmer (2015), "The Next Generation of the Penn World Table" American Economic Review, 105(10), 3150-3182, available for download at www.ggdc.net/pwt

97700.name: World trade based on own estimates (% of GDP) (Klasing and Milionis (2014))
97700.description: World trade as a share of GDP based on Klasing and Milionis' (2014) own estimates. Klasing and Milionis (2014) use non-PPP adjusted GDP estimates.
97700.datasetName: World trade based on own estimates (% of GDP) (Klasing and Milionis (2014))  (split)

source.name: Klasing and Milionis (2014)
source.dataPublishedBy: Klasing, Mariko J. and Milionis, P. (2014). "Quantifying the Evolution of World Trade, 1870-1949". Journal of International Economics 92(1), pp. 185-197
source.additionalInfo: For consistency, the 62 countries used in Klasing and Milionis are used to calculate the world trade to GDP ratio for the period 1950-2011. The list can be found in Appendix A2 of their paper.

97702.name: World trade - upper bound (% of GDP) (Estevadeordal, Frantz, and Taylor (2003))
97702.description: World trade as a share of GDP,  upper bound estimates.
97702.datasetName: World trade - upper bound (% of GDP) (Estevadeordal, Frantz, and Taylor (2003)) (split)

source.name: Estevadeordal, Frantz, and Taylor (2003)
source.dataPublishedBy: Estevadeordal, A., Frantz, B., & Taylor, A. (2003). The Rise and Fall of World Trade, 1870-1939. The Quarterly Journal of Economics, 118(2), 359-407. Retrieved from http://www.jstor.org/stable/25053910
source.additionalInfo: Notes on the calculation of the lower and upper bound estimates from the authors: "1500–1800: Trade growth rates from O’Rourke and Williamson [2002, Table 1; volume estimates only]. Level index derived, and scaled by world GDP levels from Maddison [2001, Table B-18]. The “upper bound” series is then scaled to the benchmark 8 percent European trade-GDP ratio for 1780 due to O’Brien [1982], probably an overstatement of the world trade-GDP ratio. The “lower bound” series is scaled to the benchmark 2 percent world trade-GDP ratio for 1820 due to Maddison [1995, Table 2-4], possibly biased downwards relative to the long-run trend because of the blockades during the Napoleonic Wars."

97703.name: World trade - lower bound (% of GDP) (Estevadeordal, Frantz, and Taylor (2003))
97703.description: World trade as a share of GDP,  lower bound estimates.
97703.datasetName: World trade - upper bound (% of GDP) (Estevadeordal, Frantz, and Taylor (2003)) (split)

source.name: Estevadeordal, Frantz, and Taylor (2003)
source.dataPublishedBy: Estevadeordal, A., Frantz, B., & Taylor, A. (2003). The Rise and Fall of World Trade, 1870-1939. The Quarterly Journal of Economics, 118(2), 359-407. Retrieved from http://www.jstor.org/stable/25053910
source.additionalInfo: Notes on the calculation of the lower and upper bound estimates from the authors: "1500–1800: Trade growth rates from O’Rourke and Williamson [2002, Table 1; volume estimates only]. Level index derived, and scaled by world GDP levels from Maddison [2001, Table B-18]. The “upper bound” series is then scaled to the benchmark 8 percent European trade-GDP ratio for 1780 due to O’Brien [1982], probably an overstatement of the world trade-GDP ratio. The “lower bound” series is scaled to the benchmark 2 percent world trade-GDP ratio for 1820 due to Maddison [1995, Table 2-4], possibly biased downwards relative to the long-run trend because of the blockades during the Napoleonic Wars."
